question: What factor(s) determine the maximum static frictional force between an object and a surface?
options: The relative roughness of the two surfaces in contact and the magnitude of the normal force
The coefficient of kinetic friction between the two surfaces

question: According to Newton's third law of motion, when you push against a wall, the wall pushes back with equal force. Why doesn't the wall move?
options: The wall's inertia prevents it from moving.
The wall does not experience any force.
The force you exert on the wall is greater than the force the wall exerts on you.

question: Which of the following statements is true regarding mass and weight?
options: Mass and weight are unrelated concepts and do not affect each other.
Mass and weight are the same thing and can be used interchangeably.
Mass is the force of gravity acting on an object, while weight is a measure of the amount of matter in an object.
Mass is a measure of the amount of matter in an object, while weight is the force of gravity acting on an object.

question: Which of the following statements is true regarding static friction?
options: It always opposes the motion of an object.
It depends on the velocity of the object.
It is always greater than kinetic friction.
It is independent of the surfaces in contact.

question: What is the relationship between the coefficient of kinetic friction and the magnitude of the frictional force?
Which of the following factors affect the magnitude of the frictional force between two surfaces?
Which of Newton's laws explains why a seatbelt is necessary when a car stops suddenly?
What is the relationship between the mass of an object and its acceleration when the same force is applied to it?
If the normal force acting on an object increases, what happens to the maximum static frictional force?
How does the coefficient of static friction affect the maximum static frictional force?
options: The higher the coefficient, the lower the maximum static frictional force.
The coefficient only affects kinetic friction, not static friction.
The higher the coefficient, the higher the maximum static frictional force.

question: A force of 150 N pushes a box. Starting from rest, the box achieves a velocity of 1.50 m/s in 2.5 s. Find the coefficient of sliding friction between the box and the floor. a = (vf - vi ) / t
Two masses of 8 kg and 12 kg are tied to each end of a string passing over a massless and frictionless pulley. Find the resulting acceleration of each mass.
From a cable, it is used to accelerate a 100−kg body vertically upward at a constant rate of 1 m/s2. What is the maximum tension in the cable in N? Use g = 10 m/s2.
A 1000−kg mass elevator has an acceleration of 1 m/s2. What is the tension in the supporting cable if the elevator is ASCENDING? Assume g = 10 m/s2.

A box weighing 100 N starts to move across a horizontal surface when a horizontal force of 25 N is applied to it, but a force of only 20 N is needed to keep it moving in uniform motion. What is the coefficient of kinetic friction?
An unbalanced force of 50 N acts on an object weighing 100 N. What acceleration is produced?

A 100 kg mass lies on a frictionless table and a cord is attached to one end as shown. The cord passes over a massless, frictionless pulley at the edge of the table while a 10 kg mass hangs at the other end. Find the acceleration.
A 75−kg box is pulled over a rough surface using a horizontal force of 100N at a constant velocity. Find the coefficient of friction between the box and the surface.
A 45 kg object rests on a 30° inclined plane. What force is exerted down the inclined plane?
A car of mass m is at the top of an icy 15° slope whose length is 30 m. Find the acceleration of the car. Icy surface means frictionless.
